title: Cat. 122  Beaker or Goblet, 2nd/3rd century A.D.
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Beaker or Goblet  
2nd/3rd century A.D.  
Roman, eastern Mediterranean  
Glass, blown; h. 11 cm (4 1/4 in.); diam. 7.5 cm (2 7/8 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1944.450

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Bubbly colorless glass with a greenish tinge. Blown and tooled. The rim, rounded by reheating, has faint spiral ribbing from tooling below the rim on the body. A bell-shaped beaker form with the long, flared upper body tapering inward to a short, squat globular bottom. Below, the wall tapers, bending down and in sharply, then is tooled to form a short solid stem. The base was applied to the stem with a kicked underside and an edge rounded by reheating. There is a pontil mark. For a zoomable image, see fig. 122.1.

The beaker is intact, the surface is extensively pitted with some patches of creamy weathering product on the base with overall brilliant and silvery iridescence.

The fabrication of this vessel is quite unusual and appears to have no close parallel. It does relate to a metal lamp form with a very similar profile found in a first- or second-century-A.D. settlement at Naaldwijk in the Netherlands.

The curvilinear profile of this beaker is a variation on a Roman chalice. There are several later footed beakers in the Corning Museum of Glass that relate to the form but have a less sharply attenuated profile. Related to the Corning examples is a footed beaker in the Toledo Museum of Art with spiral ribbing.  
Sidney Goldstein

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Boeselager, “Zur Datierung der Gläser,” p. 33, fig. 19.
